body: On April 8, 1968 (four days after Martin Luther King Jr.’s assassination), Coretta Scott King led a silent march through Memphis with approximately 40,000 particpants. Broadsides reading “HONOR KING: END RACISM” and “UNION JUSTICE NOW!” were affixed to wood and made into signs for marchers to carry.
sourceText:
**Sources**

“April 8, 1963, Silent march to honor King, support sanitation workers.” *King Encyclopedia*, Stanford University.

"Before I'll Be a Slave, I'll Be Buried in My Grave," *Civil Rights Movement Veterans*. http://www.crmvet.org/images/imgslave.htm.

“Dr. King's Assassination.” *Civil Rights Digital Library*, Digital Library of Georgia, 2013.

“Honor King: End Racism!” *The Kinsey Collection: African American Art & History*, 18 Jan. 2015.

*Vectorized by Signsignsigns.*

figures.caption: **Marchers on April 8, 1968. Photographer unknown, image via Civil Rights Movement Veterans.**

title: HONOR KING: END RACISM!
